stream_context.summary: Kaze hosts Sauraen (author of the F3DEX3 custom N64 microcode) to diagnose why F3DEX3 is slower than expected in Return to Yoshi’s Island. They establish performance baselines (EX2 vs older/newer EX3), discuss architectural differences in vertex/lighting processing, attempt A/B tests (disabling lighting; attempting to remove occlusion-plane work), then add new microcode instrumentation to measure time spent specifically in vertex vs triangle processing. Outside the profiling, Kaze shows progress on a Mario Kart–themed “retro pipe” section (Course 12), discusses upcoming set pieces (train race, Boshi shootout), and briefly addresses real-world ROMhack resale/repro carts seen at conventions.
stream_context.significance_reason: A major technical profiling milestone: Sauraen and Kaze add new, custom performance counters to F3DEX3 to isolate vertex vs triangle time and reveal a still-unexplained ~8–9ms overhead in RTYI’s graphics task, shaping the next phase (potential “F3DEX2.5” microcode variant and deeper profiling).

findings.summary: Sauraen restates F3DEX3’s design goals: add new N64 rendering features while reducing RDP time (faster rasterization), accepting higher SP/RSP cost; RTYI appears to have shifted to being RSP-bottlenecked once RDP time is reduced.

They suspect earlier profiling was misleading: Sauraen expected RTYI had ~8ms RSP time (plenty of headroom), but corrected numbers put RTYI closer to ~16ms RSP in the problematic scenes—leaving little slack once EX3 increases vertex-processing work.

Sauraen explains a key architectural tradeoff: F3DEX3’s more straightforward pipeline transforms vertices to world space and clip space and transforms/normalizes normals per-vertex (beneficial for features like point lights and octahedrally-encoded normals), while F3DEX2 can be faster for basic directional lighting by transforming lights into model space per bone and doing fewer per-vertex transforms/normalizations.

Kaze clarifies RTYI’s lighting strategy: environments are largely vertex-colored (no per-vertex lighting); dynamic lighting is mainly for moving actors, with a sun-direction concept per level and up to ~7 runtime-computed directional lights in some levels. Point lights are avoided for emulator friendliness; local light effects (e.g., fire) are “faked” via vertex colors and/or CPU-side logic.

Baseline measurements in the same scene show: older F3DEX3 build ~21.7ms GFX time; F3DEX2 around a similar range; modern F3DEX3 ~27ms—about ~20% worse—despite expectations that EX3’s RDP savings would help overall frame time.

A test that disables all lighting in the microcode only improves performance by ~2ms, indicating lighting isn’t the main cause of the modern EX3 slowdown in RTYI (or that the slowdown is dominated by something else).

Sauraen adds new instrumentation to F3DEX3: replacing prior counters with two U32 counters that measure RSP cycles spent in vertex processing and triangle processing. This enables a clearer breakdown than the earlier mixed counters (and requires Kaze to update RTYI’s yield-data footer parsing and UI).

With the new counters on hardware, Kaze sees ~10ms in vertex processing and ~8ms in triangle processing (≈18ms total), but the overall graphics task remains ~27ms—leaving ~8–9ms unaccounted for (neither vertex nor triangle time), suggesting an additional overhead source in the microcode path (e.g., other commands/overlays/stalls/housekeeping).

They rule out at least one suspected “degenerate” cause: display-list command count looks normal (~8,000 commands in the scene), similar to Sauraen’s OoT benchmarks, so excessive command dispatch alone likely doesn’t explain the missing time.

They examine RDP efficiency via a “Gclk alive” type metric: RTYI appears relatively RDP-efficient (a little over half the time doing useful work rather than stalling), which supports the theory that RTYI is comparatively less RDP-bottlenecked and thus exposes RSP-side costs more sharply than other games.

Sauraen floats a next-step direction: potentially create an “F3DEX2.5” for RTYI—keeping EX3 features where needed but backporting EX2-style vertex/lighting processing to reduce RSP cost—depending on what further profiling shows.

Kaze describes seeing N64 repro carts with ROMhacks sold at MAGFest (including The Missing Link) and notes the uneasy reality that third parties profit off community work; Sauraen adds he’s seen online stores claiming extremely large total sales across many repro carts.
Kaze notes he still uses Project64 1.6 for convenience but acknowledges the security risk of running unknown ROMs on older emulators (malicious ROM concerns).

Course 12 is framed as a Mario Kart 64 “retro pipe” homage (part of a broader pattern: each level has a retro pipe referencing a pre-end-of-N64-lifecycle game). Kaze plans a short timed race (~40–45s), a moving train set piece (including possibly launching Mario), smoke particles (cheap via batch rendering), and desert obstacles (cacti).

Explains why F3DEX3 can trade RDP wins for RSP losses: added architectural work in vertex processing (world-space transforms, normal transforms/normalization, point-light-friendly calculations) can become a bottleneck when a project like RTYI is already RDP-efficient.

Implements and ships new profiling instrumentation (vertex-time and triangle-time counters in RSP cycles), and guides Kaze through the required engine-side changes (yield footer format changes; conversion/divisor differences between CPU vs RCP cycle domains).
After initial tests, commits to spending 1–2 weeks thinking through deeper profiling to locate the missing ~8–9ms overhead and then returning for another focused debugging session.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I just want to make my N64 game. Ideally, I wouldn’t have to deal with emulators at all.
memorable_quotes.context: Said during toolchain/performance friction, capturing his core motivation and the ongoing emulator-versus-hardware tension shaping RTYI’s technical choices.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: It was a bizarre experience… I saw… N64 repro carts with ROMhacks on… and there was one that was The Missing Link… they were selling that for $50… somebody is just taking our stuff and selling it.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze recounts encountering ROMhack resale in the wild, a strong documentary beat about ownership, community labor, and the gray market.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: You gotta have some tolerance for that in order to be in this. It’s gonna happen.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze’s resigned acceptance of repro-cart profiteering—useful as a character moment and a prompt for deeper interview discussion about ethics and impact.

key_stories.title: Profiling why F3DEX3 is slower in RTYI than expected
key_stories.summary: Kaze brings Sauraen on-stream to diagnose why RTYI performs worse on modern F3DEX3 despite the microcode’s intended RDP savings and feature gains. Their investigation shifts from assumptions about lighting cost to a clearer measurement breakdown, revealing significant unexplained overhead beyond vertex/triangle processing.
key_stories.challenge: Modern F3DEX3 shows a ~20% worse GFX task time in RTYI (~27ms) compared to older builds/baselines (~21–25ms), threatening the planned microcode transition (and breaking lighting/GBI compatibility in the interim).
key_stories.process: They A/B test EX2 vs older/newer EX3, disable lighting in the microcode, attempt to remove occlusion-plane work (with some breakages), then implement new microcode performance counters measuring RSP cycles spent specifically on vertex and triangle processing. They also sanity-check command counts and RDP efficiency metrics.
key_stories.outcome: New counters show vertex (~10ms) + triangle (~8ms) ≈18ms, but total remains ~27ms, implying ~8–9ms overhead elsewhere. They rule out “too many display-list commands” as the main cause and plan deeper profiling and possibly a custom ‘F3DEX2.5’ variant tuned for RTYI.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s not just that the vertex processing is slower… something else is taking a ton of time.

key_stories.title: Choosing RTYI lighting that won’t break emulators
key_stories.summary: A technical design choice emerges during the microcode discussion: RTYI deliberately avoids point lights and keeps most environments vertex-colored. This anchors performance and compatibility decisions to a player-facing goal—broad emulator stability—and influences what microcode features are actually worth paying for.
key_stories.challenge: Point lighting and advanced per-vertex lighting features can raise RSP cost and introduce compatibility/performance risk on emulators, conflicting with RTYI’s accessibility targets.
key_stories.process: Kaze explains that scenes are vertex-colored; only actors use runtime directional lighting (including multiple directional lights in some areas). Local light effects are faked via baked vertex colors or CPU-side calculations rather than true point lights.
key_stories.outcome: RTYI’s rendering approach narrows the microcode optimization focus: reducing general vertex/triangle overhead matters more than point-light optimizations, pushing Sauraen toward RTYI-specific tuning (potential ‘EX2.5’ approach).
key_stories.key_quote: No, absolutely not [point lights] because I want to make sure it runs fine on emulators.

key_stories.title: Seeing ROMhack work resold on repro cartridges
key_stories.summary: Kaze describes encountering The Missing Link sold as a paid repro cart at MAGFest and reflects on how common it is for third parties to profit from community ROMhack labor. The moment adds real-world stakes and ethical ambiguity beyond pure engineering.
key_stories.challenge: ROMhacks circulate in gray markets where sellers monetize the work without compensating creators (and without money going to Nintendo either).
key_stories.process: Kaze recounts speaking to a vendor selling the cart and contextualizes it as an expected (but uncomfortable) part of being in the scene; Sauraen adds broader examples of large-scale online repro sales.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze lands on a pragmatic stance—acceptance—while acknowledging how strange and unfair it feels. This is fertile ground for an interview segment about motivation, ownership, and coping with exploitation.
key_stories.key_quote: Somebody is just taking our stuff and selling it.

open_questions.topic: Unexplained ~8–9ms overhead in F3DEX3 beyond vertex/triangle time
open_questions.context: New counters attribute ~18ms to vertex+triangle processing, yet the total GFX task is ~27ms in the same scene, suggesting another source of cost (overlays, command handling, stalls, bookkeeping, or measurement artifacts).
questions: When you saw that vertex+triangle time didn’t account for the total, what hypotheses did you prioritize (overlay thrash, command parsing overhead, RSP/RDP sync behavior, something RTYI-specific in the display lists)?
What’s the cleanest reproduction case you can build (small scene, controlled display list) that still shows the missing ~8–9ms?
If the culprit turns out to be RTYI’s display-list patterns rather than microcode alone, what changes to the engine/GBI are you willing (or unwilling) to make?
How did this discovery change your confidence in fully switching RTYI to F3DEX3—and what would “good enough” performance look like for you?

open_questions.topic: Why modern F3DEX3 regressed vs older F3DEX3 in the same spot
open_questions.context: They observe older EX3 timing around ~21–25ms, but modern EX3 around ~27ms with ‘no changes’ apparent on Kaze’s side, implying a regression due to added features (e.g., occlusion plane work) or new architectural cost.
questions: Between the older EX3 build and the current EX3, which specific features or architectural changes are the top suspects for the regression in RTYI?
Is there a commit range where performance clearly drops in RTYI, and can you bisect it with a minimal RTYI test scene?
Do you think RTYI’s relatively efficient RDP usage makes it an unusual ‘worst case’ for EX3’s current vertex path compared to other projects?

open_questions.topic: Potential ‘F3DEX2.5’ microcode tuned for RTYI’s needs
open_questions.context: Sauraen suggests a hybrid microcode: keep EX3 improvements but backport EX2-style directional-lighting/vertex processing to reduce RSP bottlenecks (since RTYI avoids point lights and heavily uses vertex colors).
questions: What exact RTYI requirements would define ‘EX2.5’ (must-have EX3 features vs features you can drop), and how would you validate them against real levels?
What would you lose artistically/visually if EX3-specific lighting paths are replaced with EX2-style processing?
How would you decide whether to solve this with microcode changes versus changing RTYI’s rendering patterns (batching, command ordering, material state changes)?

open_questions.topic: Creators’ stance on repro carts and resale of ROMhacks
open_questions.context: Kaze and Sauraen discuss seeing ROMhacks sold on repro carts (MAGFest booth; high-volume online sellers), and Kaze expresses reluctant acceptance as a reality of the scene.
questions: How did it feel in the moment to see your work sold as a physical product by someone else—did it change how you think about releasing RTYI?
Where do you personally draw the line between ‘inevitable distribution’ and exploitation—and has that line moved over time?
Have you considered any practical responses (messaging, licensing language, anti-repro boot code, or just ignoring it), and what tradeoffs do you see in each approach?
